comments:
I often have the case, that I can design and save a diagram file with a GMF-created application, but when I try a previously created diagram, I get a fatal null pointer exception (see stack trace at the end).

How to reproduce:
1.) unzip and import the attached project
2.) create the generator model and the diagram code
3.) fix the two compile errors in the leonardo2.diagram project by inserting 
    a super-constructor call with appropriate arguments into the two 
    ArtifactType-constructors (for some strange reason there are two such 
    constructors, one in:
        leonardo2.diagram.edit.parts.ArtifactTypeEditPart.java
    and one in:
        leonardo2.diagram.edit.parts.ArtifactType2EditPart.java

    Both classes need to read:
    /**
     * @generated
     */
    public class ArtifactFigure extends
        org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.diagram.ui.figures.NoteFigure
    {

        /**
         * @generated NOT
         */
        public ArtifactFigure() {
            // INSERT THIS LINE:
            super(1,1,new org.eclipse.draw2d.geometry.Insets(1,1,1,1));
            // END OF INSERTED
            this.setForegroundColor(org.eclipse.draw2d.ColorConstants.black);
            ...
        }
        ...
    }
    Save, rebuild and then launch the created application (a .launch file with
    appropriate configuration is part of the project).

4.) Create a new project in the runtime workspace and in it create a new
    empty "Leonardo2 Diagram" file.

5.) Create an Artifact, Process or Instance element - but no 
    ArtifactContainer, yet!
    Save the diagram, close the view. 
    Re-open the just created .leonardo2_diagram file - this should work. 

6.) Now create an ArtifactContainer element. you don't need to connect or
    anything else - just create it. 
    Save the file, close the view.
    Re-open the .leonardo2_diagram file => You get the below exception.

7.) At this point you can delete the two generated .leonardo2 and
    .leonardo2_diagram files and repeat from step 5.


It would be nice, if the programmer got *some* hint or clue why this fails. 
Probably some additional validation required...

Michael

Created an attachment (id=52994)
The mentioned project to recreate the exception

> How to reproduce:
> 1.) unzip and import the attached project
I downloaded the attachment, unzipped it and imported leonrado2 project.

> 2.) create the generator model and the diagram code
For step 2) I'm right-clicking on leonardo2.gmfmap file and selecting "Create generator model..." to create generator model, this gives an exception in the log:

org.eclipse.emf.ecore.xmi.PackageNotFoundException: Package with uri 'http://www.eclipse.org/gmf/2005/mappings/2.0' not found. (platform:/resource/leonardo2/model/leonardo2.gmfmap, 7, 68)

The same thing happens when I'm just trying to open leonardo2.gmfmap in the editor (double-clicking on it in the package explorer), so editor for it cannot be opened.

I'm guessing that you don't have this behavior, correct? Could you tell me which GMF version you're using? (just in case: what are the version of the other components GMF depends on: EMF, GEF, EMFT: Transaction, Query, OCL, Validation?)

> I'm guessing that you don't have this behavior, correct? 

Right - these steps worked for me. In fact, that was the point: everything worked fine, only at runtime things failed.

> Could you tell me which GMF version you're using? ...
> just in case: what are the version of the other components GMF depends on: 
> EMF, GEF, EMFT: Transaction, Query, OCL, Validation?)

Not 100% sure (I have upgraded to the next version since), but judging from misc. file dates (I always keep 1-2 back-versions in case I hit some show stopper) that must have been:

GMF: 2.0M2
EMF: 2.2.1
GEF: 3.2.1
EMFT: all 1.0.1

I agree: those are all slightly younger (i.e. higher) than the stated prereq's, but so far that has never been a problem (I think...).

HTH,
Michael

Created an attachment (id=54489)
Corrected Ecore model file

>It would be nice, if the programmer got *some* hint or clue why this fails. 
>Probably some additional validation required...

The NPE happens because your ArtifactContainer has a wrong semantic element. Semantically it's an Arifact, but notationally it's an ArtifactContainer. When ArtifactContainerName edit part tries to get the name for ArtifactContainer it looks at the info stored in the semantic element. To grab the proper info a feature id code is passed to the semantic element. It appears that Artifact and ArtifactCaontainer have different codes for the "name" feature. At some point, semantic element is asked to provide a feature object for the feature id code and due to the wrong feature code this object is null and eventually you get an NPE.
If you comment out the code for extracting ArtifactContainer label's text, it will be drawn correctly (no exceptions), but then once you try to place an Artifact inside ArtifactContainer you'll get more exceptions: because semantic element of your ArifactContainer is Artifact and Artifact children cannot be added to it.

Solution: in your leonardo2.ecore file look at the ExtendedMetaData under ArtifactContainerType, the "name" field there reads: "ArifactType", which is a duplicate of the "name" field under ArtifactType->ExtendedMetaData. Since you have these duplicates the EClass that creates the semantic element for your Artifact and ArtifactContainer is an EClass for Artifact and you have all these problems afterwards.
To solve this problem you should have a value for "name" field in ArtifactContainerType->ExtendedMetaData different from same fields of other classifiers. Just put value "ArtifactContainerType" through properties under ArtifactContainerType->ExtendedMetaData->name (in fact any other string except those used by other classifiers would work as well) The corrected .ecore file is attached.

This kind of validation is not supposed to be done in GMF at the moment. In fact, if validation against this use case to be done, this, most likely, should be implemented in EMF.

Seems that there is already a bug logged against those compile errors after code generation.

Michael, could you please confirm that after the correction to leonardo2.ecore as I'm suggesting exceptions problem goes away for you? (I attached corrected leonardo2.ecore just in case) FYI: Once, you confirm that, I'm going to mark the bug as "invalid".

(In reply to comment #4)
> ...
> Michael, could you please confirm that after the correction to leonardo2.ecore
> as I'm suggesting exceptions problem goes away for you? (I attached corrected
> leonardo2.ecore just in case) FYI: Once, you confirm that, I'm going to mark
> the bug as "invalid".

Yes - it worked! Thanks!
Michael
